code_value: In 1881 the number of women who had graduated from college was small, and those who had achieved this milestone cherished the companionship of their peers. One autumn, 17 of these women gathered for a meeting in Ellen Swallow Richards's chemistry laboratory at MIT. In January of the following year, 65 women met in Boston. Their purpose was the creation of a group to support women's education. Marion Talbot, one of the first women to enroll at Boston University, described some of the projects she thought they might take on.
